numbered_ace_sentences: 1. There is an obvious correlation between the income of parents and the likelihood that a student gets accepted into an Ivy League college.
2. If a parent of a student attended an Ivy League college then the chance that the student gets accepted is about doubled at every income level.
3. If a close relative of a student attended an Ivy League college then the chance that the student gets accepted is about doubled at every income level.
4. The acceptance rate slightly increases at the low end of the income spectrum.
5. This increase is presumably because of financial aid.
6. I wonder why the Ivy League college system is like this.
7. If a student is extremely wealthy then the chance that the student gets accepted is significantly larger.
8. I think that Ivy League colleges want rich people to attend their schools.
9. I think that rich people pay a large amount of under-the-table money to Ivy League colleges.
10. I think that rich people pay this money to get their sub-par children accepted into renowned schools.
11. I think that if so-called elites attend Ivy League colleges then the colleges claim a right to raise tuition.
12. I think that if so-called elites attend Ivy League colleges then the colleges become more prestigious.
13. I am a high school junior.
14. I want to go to a good college.
15. I am curious about acceptance rates versus income.
16. I am curious about other factors such as legacy status.
17. My community consists mostly of my school and a small town.
18. Many people in my community regularly interact with me.
19. Many people in my community would be concerned about similar issues in the elite college community.
20. The headline is: Ivy League Colleges: Wealthy in Knowledge or Wealthy in Reputation?
21. The headline is: Discover the astonishing magnitude of so-called elite colleges' lust for money and power.
